description:
Growing up in SF, this amazing hidden gem of Lucasfilm Headquarters was not here yet.  The real secret hidden gem(s) of LucasArts & ILM were over the Golden Gate Bridge in the North Bay.  There are more sightings of George Lucas in Marin County than actually in the city.  We ran into him at Northgate Mall; my daughter took a picture with him - nbd! LOL
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/northgate-mall-san-rafael?select=caTxTcTckon2x1xu1cG8CQ

Now that I have kids, I'm able to bring them, especially our son (he's way more stoked than his sisters) on a random beautiful day through the Presidio.  He enjoys posing and standing next to a storm trooper or posing with any of the statues inside.  The staff are super friendly, parking is limited on their property.  It's something to check off your bucket list.  The hype is all about the Yoda Fountain, but don't set your expectations too high.  Imagination Park in San Anselmo is truly where it's at and with a statue of Indiana Jones.  
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/imagination-park-san-anselmo?select=m5Dk7z5rYieBJqROqE2EYw
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/imagination-park-san-anselmo?select=2XWzpqtBsAwjj-0bu2vS6w
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/imagination-park-san-anselmo?select=c6MF24JXpCU3GQUUhgfMDQ

I like taking out of town guests here; there's so much beauty within the Presidio.  So much to do, so little time.  As locals, we come on weekdays, as it's harder to meander around the lobby on weekends when it's usually closed.  Afterwards, we hike around the Presidio and make it a fun family outing, especially with Twilight Thursdays aka Presidio Twilight & Sunday Funday OTG!

Thanks to Yelp, there are no hidden gems anymore, but sharing is caring!   'Til next time ~ happy trails & see you on Yelp (SYOY)!
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilm-san-francisco?select=2sZtnHaSB8qaYbRl9M-5zQ
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilm-san-francisco?select=dz_24K7tyRu5dApSsQp8kA

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilm-san-francisco?select=wHsO0MVOhk0nFSq_W_QjWQ

https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilm-san-francisco?select=9f501gG--FEqGOpP8iWQaQ
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilm-san-francisco?select=t3UvJqQ1fNnRA4jQLjoHzA
https://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yoda-fountain-at-lucasfilm-san-francisco?select=9ArYTGQHlV8n_H7uJN_7-A
author: Christine R.

description:
Paid homage to the Grand Master of the Jedi Order

If one has seen any of the Star Wars films by George Lucas (and who hasn't??) this Jedi Master first appeared in the 1980 film The Empire Strikes Back. Yoda sits on a fountain at Lucasfilm in one of the most beautiful and valuable real estate in San Francisco, The Presidio! It is just outside of the Letterman Digital Arts Center.

We asked the gate attendant at the guard shack where we could find the Yoda fountain and he directed us to the building. Once inside the gate we headed to our left and the fountain was right in front of us at the Building B courtyard outdoor patio. It's free to visit Yoda. This life-size statue sits on top of a fountain while water flows from beneath. We came on a Saturday afternoon so the lobby was closed. Boo! The lobby is open to the public during weekday regular business hours. If the Star Wars Industrial Light & Magic [ILM] offices were open in the weekends, we would've been able to view more statues -- Darth Vader, Boba Fett, etc. in the lobby. 

For now we were just happy to see the Yoda fountain since the statue has become a tourist landmark! It was a short visit. Yoda is small in size but wise and powerful, he trained Jedi for over 800 years... feel the force!

Review #0977
author: May A.

description:
In 1977 I was fortunate enough to score reviewers seats to the Star Wars preview in NYC.  Never before or since have I witnessed an audience of critics rise as one in thunderous ovation when the faces of Luke, Leia, Han and Chewy faded to credits.  Adults with tears in their eyes all around me.

Many millions -- including me since -- have internalized that moment one way or another -- and this Yoda fountain at Lucasfilm is a fitting tribute to that feeling -- now more than 40 years later.

We came on a Saturday when access to the building was not available -- but the gardens -- the statuary -- and the views we were able to see are spectacular.

Yoda's simple wisdom -- "do or do not -- there is no try" has rattled around in my head since 1977 -- alongside other disparate celluloid snippets (Forrest Gumpisms come to mind).

I can't say that later reincarnations of this storyline have held my interest in the same way or degree -- but if it moves you at all -- go to this place when in the Presidio area.  

Not sure what kind of force you will find here -- maybe just nostalgia -- but it is sacred ground for fans -- and that's good enough for me.
author: Yuri Y.

description:
This small lobby is located right next to the Yoda Fountain. It is a business lobby, but has some cool statues and Star Wars related statues inside. 

Many people come by to see the film related works inside and outside the lobby. The Yoda Statue is located in a quiet courtyard outside the front doors to the lobby. 

I love all the natural light inside. What a great lobby. 

When visiting please be considerate and quiet. Actually it was very quiet and beautiful when I visited. It strangely feels like a church inside.
author: Brian B.

description:
"Fear is the path to the dark side. Fear leads to anger. Anger leads to hate. Hate leads to suffering." 

The Yoda Fountain is a pilgrimage for all Star Wars fanatics. It's almost like going to the Sistine Chapel, Jerusalem, Mecca, or sipping holy tea with the great Dalai Lama. Ok, ok maybe not as spiritual as those examples, but a tad important nonetheless. Well, at least to all you Jedi wannabes! 

"Try not. Do or do not. There is no try." -Yoda

Yoda has been part of me since I was a very young Padawan. I watched all the original movies countless of times as a youngster, in fact, I still have all 48 of my Star Wars action-figures! I no longer play with them, silly, but it's on display at my home on Tatooine. And no one's allowed to see it unless you swear allegiance to the Rebel Alliance;)

"You must unlearn what you have unlearned." -Yoda

Yoda is one Fly... green guy! The Yoda Fountain is a working fountain found at the entrance of LucasFilm Ltd. on the historic Presidio. The bronze statue is only slightly over two-feet-tall, basically life-size, but Yoda stands on a seven-feet-tall pillar. So no doubt he'll tower over you. Immortalized to look like the aged 900-year-old version of the wise little shaman as he appeared in the original Star Wars trilogy - wisdom wrinkles and all! He's one handsome Sensei! :D A little known tradition is to toss coins into the water and make a wish. Preferably a thoughtful wish, Yoda has great patience, but little time for buffoons, or creeps that look like Gollum, or Mr. Farley. I mean c'mon now;) 

"To be Jedi is to face the truth, and choose. Give off light, or darkness, Padawan. Be a candle or the night." -Yoda

All in all, I highly recommend visiting the Yoda Fountain for Star Wars fanatics, casual Jedi wannabes, movie buffs, or anyone who wants to meet the Grand Master of the Jedi Order! The kids will love him, and grandma might even fall in love;) 
And maybe the greatest part of this pilgrimage is Yoda's not found in a Galaxy far, far away... but here he stands humbly atop a pillar... waiting to share his great wisdom with you. As someone wise once told me... "There is no trying to fall in love with this Yoda fountain, you just do, or do not. There is no try." 

And... 

"May the Force be with you... always." Amen.
author: Eric R.

description: Quirky tourist stop. The location has a university feeling to it. It was not crowded at all so was able to get great pictures. Peek into the windows behind the fountain to spot R2-D2, darth vader, and more inside the building.
author: Isabel D.

description: It's Yoda in the heart of the Presidio where the Letterman Hospital once stood. It is easily accessible with a Starbucks right around the corner. Just park in a lot close by and walk to the front entrance.
author: Gerald H.

description:
I've watched all the Star Wars movies because of my ex-- he made me watch all of them when we were together. Anyhow.. the movies were pretty interesting, but I definitely like the newer ones more since it's more modern. Lol.. 

Still, it was cool to see the Yoda statue. My sis and I stop by here sometime late last year to take pictures with Yoda. Haha.. If you're a Star Wars fan, then you most certainly should go here for sure.
author: Amy C.

description:
In a galaxy far, far away...

A disturbance was sensed in the Force. 

Master Yoda rose from his meditation and said...

"HmmPmh. To the Presidio of San Francisco to set balance to the Force again, I must go."

When Master Yoda arrived, a military base was already established in the year 1776. In Yoda's tireless efforts to once again bring peace, he vowed to stay until harmony was restored among the land. 

The military base was finally decommissioned on Oct. 1st of 1994. After 219 years of service, Master Yoda balanced the Force and returned to his home. 

A statue of him remains in the Presidio until this day, commemorating his great and selfless sacrifice. Water flows freely from the fountain where his image resides. 

Master Yoda once said, "A Jedi uses the Force for knowledge and defense, never for attack. Always pass on what you have learned." 

Disclaimer: Yoda is fictional. Total heartbreaker, I know. 

All kidding aside, Lucas Film chose to build their headquarters within Presidio and a Yoda fountain does exist for mega fans to enjoy. 

For all the hardcore Star Wars fans, it's truly a site worth seeing. Geeks and nerds rejoice and may the Force be with you.
author: Ann S.

description: Star Wars fans have to check this place out. If you're one of the many tourists running around the city you'll probably find yourself around the Presidio. Luckily for you, this fountain is a hidden gem and is quite a sight to see. The Yoda fountain is in front of the Lucasfilm lobby which can be difficult to find considering that they don't exactly have a huge sign proclaiming their existence. But the Presidio has many maps scattered all over the parks, so just go to Letterman Dr. and you'll be able to navigate from there.
author: Jermaine C.

description:
Free parking.

There is just literally a statue of yoda outside. Inside is a small room of memorabilia. I wouldn't make a trip here just for this. If you are in the presidio, stop by.

Please note: this review is coming from a non Star Wars fan.

Came here for the hubs
author: Jenny L.

description: A nerd Mecca, this is the real San Francisco treat. Yoda in statue form. It's positioned outside the Presidio's Lucasfilm complex & not far from the Walt Disney Family Museum & is an ideal photo op for Star Wars fans.
author: Shawn F.

description:
If you're a Star Wars fan and happen to be visiting San Francisco, there's no reason not to stop here to check out this fountain for a quick picture.

Parking is free, and it wasn't very crowded at all. It's also easy to find, and the security at the check in was very easy going and helpful.
author: Rob W.

description: Yoda, we found you! :) Discovered this place while in SF and wandered over after getting some croissants at Arsicault. We had just watched Star Wars: the Last Jedi, so great timing to visit the outside of Lucasfilms (it was a Saturday, so the inside was closed). Some nice trails and views around the buildings and premises, so you'll spend a good 20-30 minutes here for sure.
author: Yonnie C.

description:
Everyone I know who has found the Yoda fountain is a local. When I visit SF I am pretty much playing a tourist and it is really nice to discover old things in the Bay. We were driving through the Presidio when I remembered the Yoda Fountain was somewhere around there. Luckily it was right around the corner from us! Thank goodness for cell phones and quick thinking.

We pulled over into one of the lots and took a short walk over to the fountain. It was great since we were with kids and they could run around on the grass and pathways. The Yoda Fountain is small but lit up and if you are a Star Wars fan, it is really quite epic!

Our visit was like experiencing a little museum since the open lobby is filled with all sorts of memorabilia, life size character models, costumes, and awards. We took our time to go through everything and really admire the details. It's a working lobby for the employees and company so be respectful and keep your voices down. I did my best not to be embarrassing while I geeked out. The Yoda Fountain is well worth the detour. Reserve at least 30 minutes of your time for it if you are including the lobby tour and rubber necking all the cool office windows. Love a creative space! It's like a trip down memory lane as many Lucasfilm movies are so recognizable.
author: Rachel A.

description:
Wow it's amazing that they let you in to take pictures of the popular Ypda Fountain. I was reading through the reviews and saw that it was free as well. I went to Walt Disney Family Museum and another family told me that the Yoda fountain was across the street. So after I was done at the museum I went across the street looking for then I realized it wasn't and that it was about a 30 minute walk. 

We took our car over there and was stopped at the security booth. I was hoping that there wasn't any special event going on because I read that they do close it to public for special or private events. The gentleman at the gate was very nice. We told him, "Hey we are here to see the Yoda fountain" he asked were we where coming from and made small talk. He then directed us to the parking stalls and told us where to walk towards. For being asked the same thing over and over again he made us feel like we were the only ones that asked him all day. 

People just go to the Yoda fountain take a couple pictures, wait there turn, and continue on. It's a quick park and photo opportunity and then you're on your way again. Seeing that Yoda Statue and our experience here was awesome.
author: Karen C.

description:
What an absolute must stop for Star Wars nerds if you are in SF area. This small little cute place is the Lucas film campus inside presidio.Parking attendant was kind and helpful letting us park inside the campus :)
Statue is definitely smaller than we expected but the nerd inside us was certainly not disappointed!May the force be with you!
author: Charvi N.

description: Im a Star Wars nerd! I totally had to come check this place out and drag my husband with me. Lol. Its worth checking out if you are in the area.
author: Anna G.

description:
"Fear is the path to the dark side. Fear leads to anger. Anger leads to hate. Hate leads to suffering." Yoda
I'm not a super Star Wars fan but Yoda is one character that I really like. He sort of reminds me of my martial arts teacher. My teacher had a lot of sayings, some did not make sense at first. It was cool to see the fountain with Yoda. Unfortunately, the offices were closed so we couldn't go inside to see the R2D2 and Darth Vader statues. Definitely a place for anyone into Star Wars.
author: James Y.

description: Pretty good likeness of the Jedi master, from what I remember from meeting him on Dagoba a few years back.
author: Chris B.

description: To see Yoda one afternoon I came.  For knowledge from the one and only Yoda looking. I came and found him.  Hmmmmmm. Beautiful day in the city, was it.  Yes, Flowing, the water was.  Herh herh herh.Very clean, the area was. Beautiful place to sit, it is. To many people around not. Coffee grabbed from the nearby Starbucks.  Yes With yoda I just sat.  And enjoyed the fresh air.  Herh herh herh. And to Yoda speak to me listened.  If in SF, you are.  Check out yoda, you should come.  For sure ill be back.  Yeesssssss.
author: Eric S.

description:
Nerd I am, yes. 

Of other people around the world much like millions, star wars have loved since I was a little kid and it is been an obsession for as long as I can remember. True, the fact that I live within five minutes of the yoda statue and run by it on an almost daily basis is a nerds dream. Hmmm. 

Situated inside the presidio park, symbol of the light side, the yoda statue is.  Pulsing away energy from the dark side and sith lords, like a true G yoda commands. Yes, hmmm.

Short and sweet this review is, hmmm. Must see yoda statue, yes yes yes.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
We found it! Just follow the directions carefully from your GPS and drive slowly through the Presidio in San Francisco. ..

The guard at the entrance was so nice and helpful!  He told us where to park, pointed out the building,  and encouraged us to go inside and take photos!  I didn't know what the guard was referring to. ..we just said we were there to see the Yoda Fountain and he gave us free parking! 

We didn't know that we were at LucasFilms Headquarters!  

My main goal was the fountain... It's Yoda!!!  I don't remember how I learned about it.  It just sounded cool to me and I wanted to see it for myself!  It's worth the trip. ..especially when you go inside the building!!!
author: Nadine C.

description:
While in the Presido during an SF picnic day the honey decided he wanted to see the Lucasfilms area with the Yoda fountain.

We were waved through by security and after wandering a bit, finally found the little corner this fountain was in. Yoda had gorgeous shrubbery and trees beside him, and the fountain itself was quite serene. It was a nice way to wrap up our Presido adventure - though like Yoda before me, I must admit:

"Afraid, not much there is to say, about my journey."
author: Meg T.

description:
As a Star Wars fan I wanted to see this statue for kicks and giggles. We took an uber here about 5-10 min from pier 33 (Alcatraz tour). 

The location of the studio is beautiful and tranquil much different from the city. Our uber drove a Mercedes and there was a guard who thought we were there for a meeting. So off the bat I thought we were not allowed to see the statue because google also said it was closed. But I wanted to see it anyway. When we got to it, there were people standing by the statue who seemed to work there and smoking cigarettes. They looked at us funny and it was kind of embarrassing to take pictures with a statue.

BUT this is a landmark for Star Wars fans to see. It is really common for tourist to come and take photos. So don't be shy! There is also a lobby that you can check out and take pictures in. Last minute when we ordered our uber to leave we decided to look in the lobby for a but. And I regret not being able to stay just 5 mins longer. There was a full figure of darth vader and boba fett and other small trinkets to see.
author: Sandy T.

description: For any Star Wars or film fan, this is a must-stop if you're in the Bay Area.  The Yoda Statue was sculpted by Lawrence Noble; his art is amazingly lifelike.  The sculpture and fountain are located at the entrance to Lucasfilm's Presidio campus.  Tourists can view this sculpture and walk around outside without issue, but the interior is off limits.  You can travel here on public transportation or walk on a day of exploring.  The buildings surrounding it are tasteful, like everything George Lucas does.  May the Force be with us all!
author: Alexander G.

description: This is a must for any Star Wars fan. Thanks to the help of some friendly locals, we had located the statue. The Guard at the entrance of the parking lot was friendly but gave us a time limit. It was worth the extra stop over. The entrance lobby beyond the statue is amazing, but it is a working environment, so pictures were taken quietly. A great memory that I'll never forget!
author: Maryann R.

description: Took a private tour and was sent back in time with real artifacts from all the favorites.....Star Wars, Return of the Jedi, ET, and so much more! If you want the best souvenirs make sure to visit the employee retail store. The grounds are gorgeous too!!
author: Lisa B.

description:
If you're a Star Wars fan read on! Stumbled upon this place while we were at Off The Grid in the Presidio. It truly is a life size statue of Yoda located right outside the Lucasfilm HQs. The main lobby is closed during the weekend but you can catch a glimpse of life-size models of a Stormtrooper, Boba Fett and Darth Vader.

It's only about a 10 minute walk away from the park and all the food trucks, so if you're in the area it's definitely worth stopping by.
author: Zoher Z.

description: Off the beaten path, going on a treasure hunt, found it!!!! For those diehard Star Wars fans it is a definite treat to find the legendary Yoda fountain. It is located in front of a small lobby/museum. Be sure to go inside to check out the Star Wars memorabilia and to cool off in the A/C. You will find plenty of Lucasfilm employees nearby willing to take your photo! ;-)
author: Karen D.

description:
Yoda. Lucasfilms. Wars of the Stars, yes I'm a superfan...but this was a bit underwhelming.

I never knew Lucasfilms HQ was located literally inside Presidio Park in SF! That was pretty cool information. Came here with a friend and tried to do as many touristy things that day. It was a Sunday morning I believe, and when we drove inside Presidio Park after checking out The Spire and Inspiration Point, we knew we had to hit up our main man Yoda!

There was a super friendly security dude who answered out question with a slight smirk when we asked if this was the place with Yoda. He nodded and gestured that we could park inside, so we were lucky enough to get parking a few feet away from Yoda while having a nice peek inside the glass windows of a part of Lucasfilms HQ. 

I heard they also give guest tours during working hours, so weekends are obviously going to be less exciting. BUT if you're here on a weekend, you can easily see the Yoda fountain and get a great view of the Palace of Fine Arts as you walk around the impossibly green campus of LucasFilms (we're in a drought, people).
author: Jodi H.

description: There are some great statues here and there around San Francisco and the Yoda statue is one of them. It's not really that large, although it's a statue of Yoda so I'm not sure how big it really should be. It sits atop a fountain and seems to have a regular stream of tourists standing in front of it taking pictures. I'm not sure if I actually qualify as a tourist, but I took the picture anyway. Worth it.
author: Dave S.

description: This is a really quick, fun stop. You can see the fountain and go into the lobby and walk around a bit. It's cool to see and it won't take up a lot of time.
author: Emily M.

description:
I can't believe I only saw this now! As I left the theater, I remember the Yoda fountain was in the Presidio so I asked my friend to direct us here! We were able to get free parking (since we were less than 45 mins stay) & walked over to the fountain! Yoda is life size!! It's awesome seeing him on top of a water fountain! I also didn't realize he was right outside LucasFilms HQ! Which I was able to go inside & look around!

We were instantly greeted by a Stormtrooper replica & I started to geek out & take photos with every replica & of every book case. There's a section not opened for the public though. I definitely enjoyed being inside for a moment!

This place is definitely for every Star Wars Fan! :)
author: Gwyne P.

description: Stopped by to see the statue a few days after Christmas and a day after Carrie Fisher passed away. I was pleased to see many cards and tokens with candles burning to honor her and express the sadness of losing her worshipfulness. Sadly the building lobby was not open, so we didn't get to see any of the cool artifacts inside, but the fountain is a must see for any Star Wars fan. RIP Carrie Fisher.
author: Goldi J.

description:
I loved seeing the yoda fountain, who knew?!
A local told us about it and I didn't think they would let us in but they  did, the staff was super nice and the parking attendant even joked with us about it. Free parking, awesome quick stop for any Lucas fan who wishes to geek out.
Staff here is very nice, I would not recommend bringing small children into the offices.
author: Zildheam D.

description:
Since we were staying at the Inn at the Presidio I had to pay homage to the Yoda fountain.

After taking some fun pics near Yoda and all of his greatness we decided to go into the lobby and view the other cool memorabilia Lucas HQ had on display. There's a life size Vader and Boba Fett that is a photo must! There's also some great framed posters on display that you've likely never seen.

After about 15 minutes in the lobby we explored the grounds a bit and really enjoyed the brisk walk. There are a few statues of film icons to visit and if you have a chance you can visit the Lucas HQ Starbucks. How cool is that?!

If you have an hour to kill I highly recommend visiting Yoda and the lobby of treasures. It was a fun stop on our way to some of the other fun SF activities.
author: Stan W.

description:
I'm a big Star Wars fan! I just had to come to LucasFilm HQ and see the Yoda Fountain. Awesome! We were able to see Darth Vader and Boba Fett too!  Pretty cool geeky stuff. 

"Do our do not. There is no try." If you're a Star Wars fan, you'll appreciate a visit here. It's a beautiful campus too.
author: May N.

description:
This Yoda fountain is indeed a great delight to Star Wars fans. It's in an alcove near Building B.  Outside the door, there is a badge reader and if you fail at accessing the code to enter the building eventually Yoda will start talking from it with a recorded message.  

After visiting here, I had the Weird Al song "Yoda" stuck in my head the rest of the day.
author: David L.

description:
Yoda told me to come and I did. I've been to this place twice and it was worth it each time. 

It's pretty much a Fountain with Yoda. That's it. Yup, that's it. However, if you're a Star Wars fan as I am, you will be entranced with the awe that is Yoda. It's honestly a great statue and I really enjoy looking at it. 

We asked a few people leaving the building if there was a way of actually going and getting a tour inside the building and they told us no. Still, it was worth it just for Yoda. 

Live long and prosper Yoda statue!
author: Benny H.

description: The Yoda fountain really is a place of total zen and mystery. The last time we went to see it was at night and they have security guard stations making sure you don't park near the building to rob them. We had someone drop us off and we ran to the fountain like 007 spies got our photos and ran off. My second experience here was completely different during the day- if you walk up to the fountain and really stare into the eyes of Yoda you will feel your soul get deeper. As a pro tip- the nearby Lucas films studio has a lobby area that you can walk into that has Darth Vader and others on display for your viewing pleasure.
author: Erica H.

description: Tourists are very welcome to visit the Yoda Fountain here at Lucasfilm. If you visit or plan a visit during working hours, employees may be among the flock of individuals out and about here. If you walk throughout the lobby, you'll find amazing pieces from their Star Wars Lineup: Darth Vader, etc. If you feel as you have extra time here, be sure to walk the park and enjoy some famous sites like The San Francisco Bridge and Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Jacob J.

description:
If a true Star Wars fan you are, journey you must to see the Yoda fountain.  Loved it my kids did. And. So. Did. I.

It is a great statue. If you don't love Star Wars, you'll just be like, "Big deal".

"And that is why you fail."
"When 900 years old you reach, look this good you will not." 

Please don't go if you do not love the master. Have respect as it is on the grounds of a campus.  "Adventure. Excitement. A Jedi craves not these things." I don't want to come back to visit and find the fountain off limits because tour buses started going.

Yes, I am a ginormous geek.
author: Ed L.

description: The Mister is a huge Star Wars fan, so of course, we had to seek out Yoda and take a picture. Mission accomplished, yes we did!
author: Rochelle R.

description:
Thanks to all the yelpers that had helped about the Yoda fountain.  I have lived in SF almost all my life and never knew about this until I came here last month.  It was super cute! I am a sucker of all things Yoda.

When we arrived we were stopped by a security guard.  We were worried that we would not be able to enter the campus.  However, the guard simply asked us what the purpose of our visit was. When I told him I wanted to see Yoda, he understood my mission...and let us in.  He also advised us that the office where other Star Wars figures were was also opened for visitors and that we should check it out.  And we did just that!

A really great place to see characters from Lucas films. The campus is beautiful. I would recommend walking around if you are ever in the area. At least say hi to Yoda!! Who knew the Presidio housed such a gem!
author: Janet E.

description:
Well worth a short detour during your time in San Francisco.

Seeing the Jedi Master atop his perch instantly brought a smile to my face.  I took a few thousand pictures and let my inner dork run wild.

I was there on a Sunday, so I couldn't go in the lobby, but I looked through the windows to see a kickass Ray Harryhausen statue, along with Boba Fett and Darth Vader costumes.

I'll be back to complete my training... and to get inside to continue my geek quest.
author: Ben B.

description:
If you like Star Wars and appreciate the work of George Lucas and his company this is a must do!  

There's nothing much to saw except it's hella cool to go see a statue of Yoda and Lucasfilm.  If you're a nerd like me you'll understand.   It's not that hard to find.  Just map it on your phone and look for the guard house.  The guard inside was very nice and told us exactly where to go and what was open.

The famous yoda fountain was very cool but you have to go inside the lobby behind the fountain as well to see all the lightsabers from the main characters, figurines, life side Darth Vader and Bobba Fett.  After you get done you can walk around the buildings.  You can see inside a lot of meeting rooms and office spaces and see little nick nacks the employees have.  I thought it was AWESOME.  My gf, not so much, but I'm glad she came with me.  

The ground are exceptionally well kept and worth a walk around if you have time.  Very beautiful scenery and you can find little hidden statues and things around.

Its crazy how something so simple can cause someone so much happiness to see.  If you are a Star Wars geek like me go and see this and feel your heart soar.  It doesn't take long but worth every minute.
author: Robert A.

description:
Adorable, he is. Ever since I heard about him, I have wanted to use the force to locate and view the legendary Jedi. One of my childhood friends posted a picture with him. The next day, on our 10 mile run over the Golden Gate - I asked her if she trusted me enough to reveal the rebel secret. 

If you are part of the Empire, please make your way to the nearest Rancor pit.

If you are part of the rebellion, read on:

Yoda is in the Presidio near Starbucks. Do not be afraid of the guards, just tell them what you are looking for & they will assist you. 

When we arrived, an Imperial spy had left their used cups lying in the parking lot. I returned them to the nearest trash receptacle. If you are a true Jedi, help to keep the Presidio clean.
author: Jenn N.

description:
"The force is not strong in her"....mumbled G. as he told me to put down my phone/map to locate the Yoda fountain on the ILM/Letterman Digital Arts Center campus in the Presidio.

Then, we found him...that little green muppet, voiced by Frank Oznowicz* that everyone loves (even CGI Yoda). And, well, we took pictures and just sat there. It's quite tranquil...even with all the other devotees, er, tourists who made the pilgrimage to get a glimpse and snap pics of this film icon. I mean, really, he *is* an icon...you can't not love this 900+ year old Jedi Master. And, you can't help but quote Yoda when you see him. I felt like a little kid, sitting there, basking in the glow of the Jedi...hoping that maybe, just maybe, I'd get a little wisdom from sitting in such close proximity. It's silly, but, hey, that's part of the magic of Star Wars. Thank you, Mr. Lucas.


*Did you know that George Lucas didn't even want to use Frank Oz to voice Yoda at first? Then, after many other auditions he called Frank back and said he wanted to use him in Empire Strikes Back. Whew!
author: Lisa A.

description:
BY THE FORCE, I'm such a blinker for Star Wars!  How do I know?  Cuz, I was a just geekin' out about the chance to recon the LucasFilm Ltd. LucasArts campus!  Located within San Fransisco's Presidio, our cruiser made planetfall on a Tuesday morning.  We were respectful & friendly to the guard and told him we were on a diplomatic mission to see the Grand Master & campus entry was smooth.  No Jedi mind tricks needed and Parking is FREE!  No signs giving coordinates, so just proceed to the left.  And sure enough, there HE is!  Like paparazzi, we were snapping hella pics at the Grand Master Yoda Fountain!  It's best described as depicting him from one of the edited scenes from Star Wars Episode III, when he first arrives on Dagobah.  It's a weekday, so bonus coolness to enter the LucasFilm Ltd. lobby and peep out more Star Wars memorabilia.  Life size Boba Fett AND Sith Lord Darth Vader?!?!  Wassup Wheezy!  Yeah, today was a GOOD day, and its ONLY 10am!!!  The chikra & I carefully obeyed local customs and departed without incident, but LOTS of cool photos.  Fun times JUST looking @ inanimate objects?!?  OmegaAxl FOR SURE!  Hah!  May The Force be with you!

Props to fellow yelper M'ia K. for the directions map posted in photos.
author: Dave A.

description: He's so cute!!  The Yoda statue sitting over the fountain in the courtyard leading up to the campus screening room is smaller than I thought it would be, but he is perfect!  He greets us, welcomes us and always puts a smile on my face!
author: Maile N.

description: Thanks to Mark at the Walt Disney Family Museum for giving a map of Presidio.  I heard of this Yoda Fountain, but didn't pay attention exactly where it was located.  I didn't even remember about it when I came to visit California!  When I saw it on the map, I was so excited!  It took a bit of a walk to find it.  The fountain is little hidden, but the security guard (who I found out used to be a Kaneohe resident and is so friendly!) helped point it out and said we could go inside the building.  It was very cool to visit Lucas Film Headquarters. It is pretty cool photo op!
author: Kim O.

description: Europeans in bikes and segways saddle up next to Yoda. He is a tourist destination, but finding him is a bit like looking for Waldo. He's not located in a high traffic tourist spot, but for those who seek out yoda, he patiently waits for you in front of Lucas Films HQ.
author: Oulie T.

description: Totally one of those "hidden" gems in the Presidio. You can find it right outside of one of the main buildings of ILM in the Presidio. It's a little hard to find, but that makes it even more fun once we found it! Yoda "spouts" out water & wisdom. ;)
author: Kari G.

description:
I'm not sure what someone has to do to get inside the building that houses the Boba Fett costume, but at least I can enjoy the amazing Yoda Fountain while I scheme.

If you're a Star Wars fan, this fountain is worth checking out. Sure, it doesn't do anything other than stay still and look awesome, but you can get a few good shots with it. Parking is free and the security people are really nice.
author: May W.

description:
Yoda. You seek Yoda!

It's a frickin' Yoda statue! What else do I need to say? I wouldn't have even known about this if is wasn't for Yelp.

I'm a little confused by the people who had a hard time finding it. The map looks pretty accurate to me. It's right there in that little courtyard.
author: Paolo D.

description:
Definitely something everyone should do if you visit SF!! Cool little statue of Yoda, life-sized, that was done by the students at the Letterman School for Digital Arts. 

After you're done seeing the statue, there's a garden nearby that's really cool to walk thru, seems very Japanese & very beautiful. And the Palace of the Fine Arts is a short walk away.
author: Tom T.

description: A little known place that, I'm thinking only locals know about in the San Francisco area Lucasfilms HQ!! It's like Star Wars heaven for us Star War nerds. When you are heading in to the Lucas HQ, tell the guard at the gate you want to take a picture of the Yoda fountain, he will tell you where you can park for free and where else you can go to look at Star War displays. You can see the thermal detonator that Leia used to rescue Han Solo from Jabba or the many different light sabers used by the Jedi! It's a great little place to check out in San Francisco. And as always......May the Force Be with You!
author: Frank D.

description:
There is nothing cooler for a geek gal like myself than to find a zen place in San Francisco with Yoda looking over you.  How cool is that?  

Yes, Star Wars I love.  Afraid to admit I am not.
author: Maria S.

description:
I actually came here with a friend because she wanted too. I will admit that this place isn't really cool unless you are a die hard star wars fan, but I will say that I did like walking around and enjoying the outdoors. 

If you're having a hard time finding this place, ask a worker. but if you can't find a worker, it is more towards behind the starbucks.
author: Susie P.

description: I never saw Star Wars but we were in the Presidio Park and wanted to find it. He is actually really small as I was expecting to see like a 4 foot thing to take a photo with. He is more like two feet haha. You can actually miss it if you dont look for it but I am sure fans love it. Make sure to bring pennies and make a wish!
author: Amy H.

description:
Might be boring if you are not a Star Wars fan, but well worth the 1 mile walk from other local attractions.  

If you park by the Walt Disney family museum, you can partake in the food truck fests on weekends and walk to Lucasfilm HQ.  From there you can walk down to the Palace of Fine Arts or the 3-4 mile trek to Golden Gate Park.  There is a lot to explore.

The statue itself is smaller than it looks online but quite nice.  If you are a hard core fan, this is a great pilgrimage.
author: Marissa L.

description: Worth a look and a picture for die hard fans! I didn't know you can go inside but I guess you can. next time!
author: Heidi H.

description: It's a fountain.  I mean that's it. Yoda is small. When you go in the building they only let you hang in the lobby. I tried going further and the secretary lady was like "scuuse me you can't go there. It's for employees."  I said " I work here". She didn't believe that. Need to work on my convicing skills.
author: Nick S.

description: It's yoda!  and it's open to the public.  A great "FREE" Star Wars stop for any fan.  If you've got friends in town surprise them with a quick stop by here :)
author: Gene X.

description: Friendly staff. Kindly told us to feel free to park in the 20 minute free parking spots in front of the building to take our fountain pictures and invited us to go into the lobby behind the fountain. Total must do for any Star Wars fan. No changing table but I'll save that for the review of the lobby. Thanks for the recommendation Yelpers!
author: Lakergirl T.

description:
What I think of you, this is, Yoda!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OJTStmogYuMCDniv91B3QQ?select=r4wmGJKpXTHT64B4d1t0kw

Sorry, Yoda, never a fan of yours, I was. 
Your ass shove the force up, bitch!
Still pretty cool though, your fountain is.
author: Craig R.

description: I heart Star Wars, I heart Star Wars.  "A padawan no more a Master I am."  Ahhh... I get super stoked when I am here. Free movie screening, courtesy of the boyfriend who is employed here.  I cannot wait to see the new SW movie.  Oh it will be epic, beyond epic.  I am totally geeking out about this.  What can I say about this glorious place, its clean and everyone just appears to be peachy.  I love that George Lucas is enhancing the Presidio neighborhood and all of the new development will bring in more beauty  to this lovely area, not that it needs it because it is already picturesque out here.  "May the force be with you."
author: Angela V.

description:
Master Yoda in all his glory.

There's a park on campus that's open to the public. No alcohol, no roller skates(blades/boards), no bicycles (you can walk with them or lock them on racks) and your pets need to be on leash (signs are posted at all entrances). Best time to visit IMO is when the cherry blossoms are in bloom.

There is also a lobby that is open to the public during business hours located in B building. Anything past the lobby doors is off limits to the public.

Also a Starbucks and seating area at C building and you can see statues of Eadweard Muybridge and Philo Farnsworth (wiki them) on the promenade walkway.

Parking can be found around the perimeter of the campus. 

Nice stop if you're in the area. Lot of sight seeing and food around like the Marina, Palace of fine arts, Crissy field, etc. Wear comfortable shoes if you plan to sight see and not just have a quick visit for Yoda. Parking is an issue anywhere around that area.
author: C T.

description:
"Do or do not, there is no try."

"When nine hundred years old you reach, look as good, you will not, hmmm?"

"If no mistake have you made, yet losing you are ... a different game you should play."

"When you look at the dark side, careful you must be ... for the dark side looks back."

With words of wisdom like these, how can you not love admiring a life size statue of our boy Yoda just steps inside the Presidio?! If you give this anything less than 5 stars, you must be Satan.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
He is about the size of a backpack!

Visit the presidio and see Yoda. That's all.
author: Steve N.

description:
Look I know not everyone will be impressed by the Yoda Fountain, but I'm a Star Wars fan so I was more than happy with my visit!  I also love that it's right next to the Palace of Fine Arts, it makes it easy to walk over from there.

My visit was on a Sunday so the room filled with all things Star Wars was closed. I did manage to take pictures through the window though. I know that the room is open during the week though, and it might also be open on Saturday.

Before my visit I read that it's complex to find it and using your navigation system won't help, but I had no such difficulty using the one on my phone to pinpoint the location.  I also read that if you drive here the security guard will stop you and ask kindly where you are headed, then allow you proceed. I'm sure this is true if you're driving but I was not asked perhaps because I was on foot.

It's free, it's Yoda,  plus awesome Star Wars memorabilia you can at least see through the window, so if you're a fan there's plenty to enjoy. If you're not a fan and someone is taking you along for the ride you can still appreciate the layout of the place, the plants and trees, and how adorable Yoda looks sitting at the top of the fountain.
author: Ursula N.

description:
This is one of the best-kept secrets in San Francisco.  

When you approach the address, you will find a Security Guard in a shack.  If you tell him nicely that you are there to see Yoda, he will direct you to your view own parking space.

BONUS: If you go during normal business hours - between 9 AM and 5 PM, Monday through Friday - they will invite you into the Lucas Films / ILM Lobby!  Inside the lobby, you will be able to explore many incredible treasures from Star Wars - including screen-used props (lightsabers, guns) and actual costumes from the films!

The best part of all: Everything here is FREE!

The folks at LucasFilms / ILM are super nice to visitors and that makes it all the more wonderful.  If you have extra time, check out the little park in the back which features statues of the "Father of Television" and the "Father of Film".

You will have a great time...and the force WILL be with you!
author: Kyle O.

description:
Totally awesome!  For any Star Wars fan visiting SF, then you must head over to the Presidio to see the fountain of Yoda!

Parking at the fountain is limited to 20mins.  There may be other places to park near the campus if you want to stay a little longer.

The lobby inside was open when I was there, and it is also a must see to see more memorabilia.  Just be respectful when walking around because it is still a place of business.
author: Vira P.

description: This is a great place to take anyone who's into Star Wars for a quick photo op. Also, the lobby behind the statue is open most days (although NEVER Sundays) where you can find some cool Lucasfilm stuff, including books, props and even a life-sized Darth Vader and Boba Fett!
author: Michael G.

description:
Awesome little secret statue in the Presidio. It's striking to me to have a statue and fountain dedicated to a fictional character (and yet the Alice statue in Central Park does nothing for my cold black heart?).

I love visiting on the weekend. You pull up to the guard and say "Can we park for a minute to see Yoda?" to which the guard replies, "Does Yoda know your coming?"

Your answer, "Surely, he felt the disturbance in the Force." A wave of your hand and a "These aren't the droids you're looking for" and you're in.

Make sure you walk into the Lucas Film / Industrial Light & Magic Lobby and check out the movie memorabilia and artifacts of inspiration.
author: Ryan S.

description: I dropped by on a gorgeous sunny day and got to hang out in Yoda's sage presence under the dappled shade of an olive tree. Lots of other people came through to take pictures with the fountain, every one of them in a good mood and excited to be there. The water made happy water-sounds and cooled the area a little. A family picnicked nearby. There are other bronzes around the area by the same sculptor (Lawrence Noble) of film pioneers Philo T. Farnsworth, Willis O'Brien, and Edweard Muybridge (my favorite since I'm a photo nerd).
author: Katie R.

description: OH man!!  Getting lost sucks but it's fine to get lost in the Presidio because it's so beautiful!!  It was my mission to find Yoda but my iPhone maps was failing on me.  It even told me I was in the Pacific Ocean at one point.  After constant driving around and around and around we finally found letterman drive!!!  I was so excited.  There was a guard at the gate but she said we can park there for 20 minutes to see Yoda.  It's a really cool fountain.  Definitely something cool and simple to see on a beautiful day in San Francisco.  :)
author: Chrissie O.

description:
How do you write a review about a fountain? LOL

Boyfriend is a Star Wars buff, so on our bicycle ride from Golden Gate Park to Presido Park I thought I'd surprise him with this "attraction." Let's just say he went nuts! hahaha it was priceless :)
author: Marilou F.

description:
Smaller than I expected... though this is supposedly life-sized.  Heh heh.

You'll have to walk your bike up to it, the security guards take their roles seriously as resident Stormtroopers.  One rolled out from the bushes and commanded me to walk my bike.
author: Erika C.

description: When in the area (perhaps for the Walt Disney Family Museum), stop by here to get your geek on. My boyfriend is a huge Star Wars fan, so he really appreciated this fountain and thoroughly enjoyed it.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Shocking, I'm sure, but yes, I am a closet Star Wars nerd.  (Shocking because I'm also a closet Trekker.)

+5 for Yoda
-1 for the unhappy Lucasfilms employee giving us the evil eye - not my fault you had to work on a Saturday in a job that most people would kill for, ya dick...
author: Patrick C.

description:
Kinda hard to write a review SOLELY about the fountain even though it is an AWESOME fountain!!! So I'll sneak in a review about ILM since I got a tour on Friday!!!

Awesome, awesome, awesome! I am a self-confessed Star Wars geek. Toured many parts of ILM with a VERY nice guy who offered my friend and I tour. Got to see some awesomely cool things. I have a broken ankle (and a pinched nerve from hobbling on the broken ankle) but that did not stop me from the tour and I was high on pure joy :)  

Obviously as a non-employee, I see the place only as a giant factory of cool and fun. With pretty interior design and the best decorating job ever! Who wouldn't want a Han (or Jar Jar) in carbonite hanging on their wall?!?! But pretty sure even the most over-worked employees would have to admit they work in a really cool place :)

My husband and several friends asked when I was submitting my resume (I wish!!!) :)

And the views from inside are gorgeous - Golden Gate Bridge and Palace of Fine Arts. And on a blue sky sunshiny day (not always guaranteed in SF), the Yoda fountain sparkles :)
author: Celeste S.

description:
I still can't believe we spent the better part of an hour looking for this statue. We walked around the back of the building, by all the other statues, eventually lulling for a while in the garden among the cherry blossom trees in full bloom before nearly giving up. 

Having already checked-in at the damned thing and wanting to make sure he made good on his inter-tron boast, my friend was determined to find Master Yoda. 

Yoda's in the FRONT of the building, close to the parking lot (we were parked in a lot deeper into the Presidio) though he's immediately visible from there. He's sort of tucked in a corner. 

Some of the previous reviewers mention that the Palace of Fine Arts can be seen from behind Yoda and that he has a view of it, which implies that he's in the back garden where we were looking for him. There are multiple buildings between the two, and you CANNOT see the Palace of Fine Arts from the Yoda statue (unless you're Superman). 

Future visitors can thank M'ia K. for the map.

My verdict: it's OK. Nothing that I would drive out of my way for in the future. 

However, that garden out back with the pond and the cherry blossoms and the view of the Palace of Fine Arts? Gorgeous. If you're in the area just to see Yoda spend some time in the garden back there. The grounds remind me of Star Fleet Academy's campus as shown in "Star Trek: The Next Generation," which is supposed to be in the Presidio (and yes, Star Wars fans, I went there).
author: Christine A.

description:
HMMMMMM awesome place- this is. 

We had seen this landmark on the TV show, The Amazing Race, and had to go see it after our trip to the Walt Disney Family Museum. The fountain is about a 1/2 mile away from the Disney Museum. 

The fountain is located in the Letterman Digital Arts Center in the court yard in front of the lobby. Don't be afraid of the security gate as you enter the parking lot. The guard just asked us why we were there and then gave us a parking permit and directed us to the fountain. 

As Yoda would say, "fortunate, you are", because the lobby was open and we got to go inside and see the statues of Darth Vader, Boba Fett and other Star Wars memorabilia. It was fun to see the "Lucas Arts" sign on the wall as well. 

The grounds are gorgeous with a neat view of the Palace of Fine Arts. There is a Starbucks located in the court yard area of the complex and is open during the week. 

It was amusing to see all of the action figures and other "geek toys" resting in the windows and on the desks of the offices. 

There are no formal tours and the place isn't real public friendly but if you are an avid fan of Star Wars or other George Lucas films, then you will appreciate just walking the grounds and being close to where it all happens.
author: Jules P.

description: Yep. We found it. It wasn't hard to find thanks to Yelper M'ia K's map! Just drive up digital films HQ and ask the guard where the Yoda statue is (on the left of the entrance). People think Yoda's at the Presidio but it's actually at the hill / grounds behind it. It's probably a 5-10 minute walk up, so pretty worth the trip.
author: Mimi C.

description: A must see for the star wars fan. Yoda status in the middle of presidio. There is even a Starbucks next to.
author: Chloe C.

description: If you are in area, you might hike over to Yoda Fountain where Letterman Hospital once sat. You pay the parking fee and maybe spend less than an hour to hike, see, go back to car. Not much else to see since this is a private working business. You cannot go into building but you can look at the Star Wars figures displayed in window.
author: Clifford W.

description: This place was so cool we went back twice on our trip to San Francisco!
author: Kimberly S.

description:
I honestly had no idea LucasArts was in the Presidio until my bf told me on our bike ride through the area. We spent the majority of our ride around trying to figure out which building was actually theirs. It was only by accident that we stumbled across the statue. 

The garden in the back is definitely worth your time but better not ride your bike through there unless you want to be yelled at. 

Overall this isn't some sort of attraction... I dont know why people are reviewing it as such. It's just like any sort of statue a business would have at their headquarters, only obviously it's so much more to outsiders because it's Yoda and it's open to the public.
author: Miffy Y.

description:
How can you not give this place 5 stars...

I came with my girlfriend to pay my respects to my old master...its been some time since I've visited Degobah and the swamp land has been industrialized to a modern city.  The new inhabitants have even built a nice crypt with a statue in honor.

Come, rub a penny with your loved one and make a wish together or ask Master Yoda to bless your union.  Or you could just take tons of .jpegs in most savory poses...wadDUUUP

ps...peep the pic i uploaded...there is no way you can top that...bahahaha
author: Brian V.

description:
Came here with my boyfriend because he is a big Star Wars fan, so we made the trek to the Presidio and ilke most of the other reviews, I was not super impressed.

Yoda is cool, but the fountain was just normal.  The stuff in the lobby is cool but I don't think this place is "meant" to be a tourist attraction?  It's almost like people are just at work there, and you're in their lobby snooping.  I tried to extend my trip by checking out the posters on the wall, reading some books in the lobby but overall, there really is not much to see. 

It's a quick worhty stop for your hard-core Star Wars fans... but definitely plan on doing other things while you're in the area.  The pictures make it look really cool.. but really.. that's all there is to see!
author: Gloria C.

description:
I had no problem finding the fountain. Just enter the Presidio entrance from Lombard and turn at Letterman. Just drive up to the security guard and ask to see the Yoda fountain.

As everyone else said, it is 30 minute parking. If ILM is open, you can go in the lobby, look around, and take pictures of the book case, signs, and statues. 

I tried to be as respectful as possible and got that in return. the receptionist was great but did tell me that I could only take pictures and tour the lobby. The rest of the building was off limits to general public. I told him I understood and asked if I could take pictures. He said, sure. I then thanked him. 

The fountain, itself, is nice. But, what sets it apart is the surrounding. Here is Yoda in the midst of some beautiful and exotic plants and trees. The setting really is cool. Walking around the campus will reveal statues of various film makers and contributors of technology to the arts. 

It is an amazing setting. I happened to roll in around lunch time, so the ILM and LucasArts magic makers were coming out on walks and smokes. I was surprised at how young that crowd was. 

It's a great experience for a Star Wars geek, as I am. It's a must see if you are in the area.
author: Mike M.

description: I knew I had to put this on the list for my Star Wars loving husband.  We got to the gate about 4pm and the girl was super nice and told us 20 minutes parking for the fountain.  We walked past it to see the lobby and the Boba Fett and Vader inside before it got crowded inside.  We took various pics then saw the fountain.  It's nice for the SW fan to see and we even got some free entertainment in the form of a dull tool in the shed driving her car over a traffic cone and it getting caught.  After futile attempts to dislodge it, she drove away with a Lucasfilm cone stuck under her car.
author: A. S.

description: It's a nice little spot and I haven't seen it get too crowded. Thanks for posting that map!!!
author: Lisa K.

description:
It was a cold, windswept day as I approached the fountain...

ME: Are you the great and wise Yoda?

YODA: My name that is...wear it out don't.

ME: You're smaller than I thought.

YODA: Size matters not. Look at me. Judge me by my size, do you? Hmm? Hmm. And well you should not. For my ally is the Force, and a powerful ally it is. Life creates it, makes it grow. Its energy surrounds us and binds us. Luminous beings are we, not this crude matter. You must feel the Force around you.

ME: What the hell is the Force?

YODA: A quarter.

ME: A quarter?

YODA: Quarter you must gimme.

I throw a quarter into the fountain.

YODA: Quarter you expect me to get from below?

ME: You want me to fish it out?

YODA: Ready are you? What know you of ready? For eight hundred years have I trained Jedi. My own counsel will I keep on who is to be trained. A Jedi must have the deepest commitment, the most serious mind.

ME: So you really think I have Jedi potential? Gee, has anyone told you that you sound just like Miss Piggy?

A clap of thunder erupts and the statue no longer speaks. Apparently, the Force giveth...and the Force taketh away...and don't take hallucinogenics on an empty stomach.
author: Ed U.

description:
Yoda rocks and he deserves to have his own fountain!

Be sure to check out the surrounding area. Walk straight down the path from the parking lot, instead of going left towards Yoda. You will see a statue of this film maker dude.

Behind the dude is an awesome view of the Palace of Fine Arts. 

There is also a beautiful park area, with well kept lawns, trees, a creek and lake.

It's just sweet... Check it out!!!
author: Sam T.

description:
We found the Yoda statue!!!!!!

Very hidden.... don't Google map Lucasfilms, just Google 1 Letterman Drive instead. The beautiful "campus" does not have any Lucasfilm signs so don't be scared to drive into the private business lot. Just let the security guard at the gate know that you are here to visit Yoda and they will direct you to the proper parking side. If you are lucky (I wasn't), the lobby area behind the Yoda statue may be open and you can walk in to see some more Star Wars memorabilia and take pictures of the LUCASFILMS sign... or you can do what I did and take pictures with my awesome camera through the lobby windows. For sure you will see Boba Fett and Darth Vader.
author: Lisa T.

description: A must see for any Star Wars fan. What's not to love about yoda? Be sure to go into the building directly behind it and get your pic taken with boba fett while you're there
author: Tessa O.

description:
Meditate here.

Yoda will guide you.  :)

Quite possibly one of my SF favorites, simple as it is.


It's not too busy if you want to check it out, but do avoid Sunday afternoons.
author: Athena S.

description: My buddy was heartbroken and depressed knowing he's a huge starwars fan and a jedi like me. Me and my wife surprised him by coming here. It is a private building so ask the guard nicely, you can also look inside their waiting area where darth vader is waiting. Ask permission and be nice. My friend was so happy.
author: Chikinini G.

description:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/OJTStmogYuMCDniv91B3QQ?select=SDegMavCVJFQkNQa0qHdQg

Make sure to visit Yoda during business hours so that the locals can give you that "Here comes ANOTHER one" look.  I got mine, and it made me smirk.
author: Nelson W.

description:
It's pretty incredible that Yoda got a fountain. Not that he doesn't deserve it, but that it's right there, in a public park just a two minute drive from my home.

I can't decide, but I think this is my favorite piece of the Star Wars Universe currently inhabiting our day to day lives.
author: Jason R.

description: Beautiful - yes. Tranquil?  Not today. Driven out by "gardeners" with ridiculously noisy polluting machines. Can't the Lucas people find less offensive machines?
author: Joan S.

description:
As Yoda once said:

"Size matters not. Judge me by my size do you?"

So yeah, don't judge the fountain by its size, but enjoy this hallmark of "local flavour" on the grounds of ILM/Lucasfilm, in the beautiful Presidio.

5 Stars!
author: I. O.

description:
+100 for yoda!
i love the place, it's pretty, chill, and nice!
author: Ru C.

description: Pretty awesome status, this is! Bring here, your nerdy friends you will, after visiting the exploratorium!

description: Ever notice that Yoda looks just like Burl Ives? What's that all about?
author: John B.

description:
What can I say.  
It's Yoda.  
He's on top of a fountain.  
And to quote my friend Randy, "It's not every day you see Yoda on a fountain."

That said, it was after hours and quiet in the parking lot.  There was ourselves and one other group of geeks who came for the photo-op.

Still, gotta see it.
author: Ken B.

description:
I heard about the infamous Yoda at Lucas Arts and walked around everywhere in the front but couldn't find him. So then i tried again but this time I took the long way (didn't know this at the time) and walked the perimeter of the grounds and stumbled upon YODA! I could not believe my eyes...there he was, immortalized for me to oogle him. I plan on coming back with light sabers!

Tip: to find him, enter from the street entrance, walk up the hill, past the statue of some guy you'll see a path. Walk down that path and to your right, Yoda you will find.
author: Janel Y.

description: Not much needs to be said here. If you are a true patron of star wars this is a destination spot for you. The grounds are beautiful. The bus stops right in front and if you go inside the lobby they have some actual pieces from the star wars movies on display.
author: Eisa m.

description:
Seriously! Yoda and I are new BFF's! OK, may not, but I really wish we were.

When I happened upon his statue while wondering the Lucasfilms headquarters/park I was super excited! All I can say is that it's a must see! Make sure to wonder the rest of the park area, because it is just so beautiful with a great view of the Palace of Fine Arts
author: Casi C.

description: Peaceful and serene on a Sunday afternoon.  Worth the trek even if he's smaller than you expect.  Nice Starbucks around the corner to rest your weary feet.
author: Danny W.

description:
Some gems aren't found in a tour guide.

The Yoda statue stands guard in front of the Letterman Digital Arts Center, which is near the Lombard St. entrance into the Presidio. The 23-acre campus retains the name of the Letterman Army Hospital that was demolished to make way for G.Lucas. Look for the guard booth for directions:

Me:  I'm looking for a Jedi Master.
Guard:  Oohhh. Jedi Master. Yoda. You seek Yoda.
Me:  You know him?
Guard:  Mmm. Take you to him, I will.

Not exactly like that, but he'll point you to the Sci-Fi shrine.

The life-size Jedi stands elevated within a small fountain with sheets of water cascading from his perch. The Force (of water) flows strongly. It's a serene place surrounded by a pristine landscape and a Starbux around the corner. Could there exist a more romantic spot for a first  kiss? Mmm. Just a thought, wouldn't it be whack if Yoda's eyes were security cameras and the IT geeks were having a big ha ha over all the nerds that flock there? Not me, other nerds.

There's a small cache of Star Wars memorabilia displayed within the building lobby behind the stone-faced Jedi. Darth Vadar, Boba Fett, light sabers, others. If you're the Sci-Fi type or your out-of-town guests are, then this is for you. May the Geek be with you.

( lengthy Yoda review it is. I am nerdy )
author: Teddy B.

description: Great place even if you have never seen any Star Wars films. I guess we were lucky today because the lobby was open and we could go inside.
author: Amy R.

description:
I'm pretty sure this fountain would only impress die-hard Star Wars fans, as it was definitely smaller than I expected. But if you're into that sort of stuff, you should also check out the plethora of Star Wars props in the lobby immediately behind the fountain. 

Oh, and you're not allowed to use the restrooms inside. When I went, some lady yelled at me and said I was trespassing. Damn my bladder.
author: JT T.

description:
Swimming with Yoda!  

Just don't forget to be nice to the guards when they kick you out....they're only doing their jobs.
author: A J.

description:
a haiku for the pilgrims...

Hard to find, he is.
A small hint the lost may need:
Not once, postman rings.
author: Steph P.

description:
"Do or do not. There is no try."

How can you not love Yoda?? 

This is a life size statue of the little guy, but it's easy to find once you drive into Letterman Digital Arts Center.
author: Connie C.

description:
Dear Mr. Lucas,

Thanks for taking a shit on my fair city. First you destroyed the Star Wars franchise and now your defiling some of the most beautiful land in the fricking world.

But In Golden Gate Park, they put up statues to Schiller and Goethe.  yeah I guess a muppet who spits eastern mysticism did far more that Goethe. You should have saved that shit for Anaheim.

But I guess every IT(diot) fanboy love this shit and it will be oozing with joy to visit this place like pilgrims to Mecca. What do you expect from a Trojan. Go back to Marin.

EDIT: As someone mentioned to me in a private message: "It would have been cooler if it was a statue of Han Solo in frozen in  carbonite." Hell Yeah. If it was Han Solo in Carbonite this review would have been 4 stars.
author: Poincare's Conjecture N.

description:
I feel like i need to preface this review by saying Yoda is awesome and there isn't a character created past or present who is as dope as him...

However, this statue was a little underwhelming... 

Like everyone else, i had a little trouble finding Yoda at first. However, i think this is because the fountain is so small that you walk right past it. When they say this is a life size replica... they mean it. I don't know what i was expecting... like a grand Yoda shrine or something... but it's really a simple, small fountain. 

The cool part is going into the Lucasfilms lobby located right behind the fountain. In there you'll find two life size statues of Darth Vader and Boba Fett-- kinda cool. Also there's a bunch of other Star Wars stuff any fan would enjoy checking out. 

I would give it 5 stars just for the ol' "Aww man it's Yoda you gotta give it 5 stars" sake.. but i think 4 stars is more than fair. I'll just say this, when you go, expect to stay less than 5-10 minutes... you'll take your picture, and say to yourself, "That's it?"
author: Greg G.

description: If you have to even wonder why this statue is worthy of 5 stars, don't  bother making the trip down here.
author: Bucky K.

description:
Typical conversation I have.

"So where do you work?"
"The Letterman Digital Arts Center"
"The wha?"
"You know, in the Presidio..."
"umm.."
"*sigh* where the Yoda Fountian is."
"Oooohhhh, COOL!  So you work for George Lucas!"

*begin explanation that not all companies in the LDAC are owned by Lucas*
author: Joshua W.

description:
The weather Saturday was almost perfect and I went for a nice walk in the Presidio just to go see Yoda.  I knew he was around Bldg B, but still couldn't find him at first.  Had to ask around, but then when I finally saw him and the fountain, I was really happy!  Definitely worth the effort.

The fountain and sculpture is so nicely done.  The perfect height and Yoda looks to be actual size or life size.  Yoda is beautifully sculpted and is so life-like and believable that I found myself walking around it to view it from all angles.  Never knew a statue to look so wise, yet so cute and adorable.

My friend noticed that others had tossed coins into the fountain and she gave me a couple, so like others before me, I made a couple wishes and tossed some coins, just like I recently did at the Palazzo in Vegas.

The Yoda fountain is very well done...for me, it was definitely worth the trip to find him.  There was a certain calmness, a peaceful serenity standing there in front of him.  I don't know who the artist was, but they totally captured the essence of Yoda perfectly.
author: Roy N.

description: Awesome place!!! kinda hard to find. It is in the back between two of the buildings around the corner from Starbucks. But definitely worrth the mission to find it!!!
author: Kristine D.

description:
As a huge Star Wars fan I decided to make a pilgrimage to this fountain. It was slightly hidden, but easy to find and personally I think going on a quest to find it was more fun than if it were super easy to find. The surrounding area is very peaceful and quite. The whole LucasFilms area was very pretty. There was even a Starbucks nearby which was nice to visit on a typical cold foggy SF day. 
Anyways, the fountain is pretty mush one of the coolest things I have seen in the city. I like how it's not well know because there aren't always a bunch of people around so it is quite and a little more private. When my friends and I got to the fountain I played the Star Wars theme as we revered in the awe of the fountain ( yeah I know, I'm such a nerd). I overheard a tour guide say that the Yoda on the fountain is a to scale replica of the Yoda from the original Star Wars movies. 
Must see landmark for all Star Wars fans :)
author: Julie C.

description:
San Francisco is a sci-fi city and this is one of our temples.  

My only wish is that they could have made a little slice of Dagobah for Yoda to stand in, and situate him better with his teachings (principly from "The Empire Strikes Back").  Yoda here is in an austere concrete fountain, not surrounded by greenery and nature, one with The Force.  He is elevated above your height, which is a bit incongruous with his teaching "Size matters not".   

Yes, I'm a geek.
author: Beau G.

description: A truly inspiration piece of art. I felt like I could FEEL The Force. Definitely worth the trip to go see. The easiest way to get there is through the Lombard Gate to the Presidio
author: Dustin H.

description: Fantastic! I finally made a trip here and paid tribute! :)
author: Yan M.

description: Good place for photos especially for star wars fans. They have a yoda fountain and a darth vader and boba fett inside. Thats pretty much it though so dont expect to spend more than 10 mins here. The park around this area is nice though so maybe you can spend another 10 mins to enjoy the scenery around lucas studios. UPDATE: the building is closed on the weekends so only the yoda fountain is available for pictures during the weekends.
author: Robert Y.

description: Well this is a cool place. I have Yoda in my profile picture too.
author: Don F.

description:
All I can say is that if you decide of take tourist/ wedding photos at the Yoda fountain, keep in mind there are dozens of digital artists watching you from the windows. :)

And please, don't try to enter the building on the weekends. :P
author: dj z.

description: very cool, free, very cool, kids and adults love it. we also wandered into Lucasfilms lobby where they had more stuff and they were cool with tourists wandering in their lobby which was nice
author: Drew H.

description:
Star Wars fans must seek out the Yoda fountain outside of the Letterman Digital Arts Center in the Presidio. How fun to find this here! Next time I will bring a camera with me. 

I stopped by on a weekend and one of the security guards explained to me that I could visit the lobby area during the week. A quick peek inside the lobby reveals a Darth Vader and Bobba Fett.

A cool plus...in a building on the other side of Yoda is a Starbucks where you can grab a coffee drink, sit outside on the patio, and take in the beauty of the Presidio.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
In the footsteps of Yoda, follow you wish...

Nice homage to Yoda at Lucas HQ. Yoda rocks!
author: Fern D.

description: This is only anti-climactic if you're not a Star Wars fan. It's not terribly difficult to find, just park and it's to your left!
author: CM P.

description: I decided to take my 5 yo nephew to see the Yoda fountain one Saturday morning a few weeks ago because he's on a sudden Star Wars kick and I thought he'd enjoy it.  We had a hard time finding it because we really had no idea where it was.  And for those that go looking, he's right in front of Building B.  Extremely easy to find once you know where it is.  He truly is life-sized.  It's a very cool statue and we were a bit disappointed that the lobby of Building B was closed since it was a Saturday.  So, the following Monday, the nephew and I went back to see the fountain again and to go into the lobby to check out the life sized Darth Vader and Boba Fett.  I think I am officially the best aunt EVER now!
author: Kris L.

description: Nice fountain.  There are a lot of really cool Star Wars like things around this campus.  Patience young Skywalker.
author: apple r.

description: My brothers and I will go here to worship. "Yuss, mmm."
author: Courtney P.

description: As a Star Wars fan, I think this is awesome.  I want to buy one for my future house.
author: Andrew K.

description: An absolute mecca for fans of the Star Wars movies.  Like my friend Bucky K says, those who don't understand the 5 stars, wouldn't appreciate it.  Also check out the life size Boba Fett and Darth Vader statues within the entrance lobby of the complex.  Although I think you can't go in there, it's just cool enough to see them from the outside.
author: patrick w j.

description: I've visited this fountain a few times. But this one time in bandcamp....uh wait. Not in bandcamp, but anyway, this one time as my hubby and I were admiring Yoda, we got up on the surrounding wall encasing the fountain that Yoda was standing on to get a closer look at Yoda's eyes and all of a sudden a guard comes running out from one of the glass doors of the Letterman Center and starts strongly urging us to get down. As if what? Me and my hubby were going to jack Yoda?! Who would jack Yoda? Fercrissakes! Jack Yoda?! My inner geek knows better, like how the Force would never allow such a thing to happen, which is why he's still there. Sitting in his fountain with some twitchy guard in the Letterman complex waiting to pounce on unsuspecting Star Wars pilgrims. Sheesh. Great statue though. Where's Chewie?
author: cora j.

description: A little confusing to find but is located in a small courtyard. But find it I did!!! Totally awesome!

description: Out of all the sites in SF how did you find a fucking yoda fountain?  Ridiculous, but sexy.

description: So... I love San Francisco. If for no other reason than I had a security guy actually yell at e by saying " Hey, you can't just climb on Yoda!".

description: I threw a penny in. Now, does this mean I get microscopic bacteria embedded in me to gain the force? Or do I get 3 wishes?
